acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: According to 72 hours ErC50>7.8mg/L of the algae (Selenastrum) (MOE Eco-Toxicity Tests of Chemicals (1996)), since the toxicity is not indicated within the upper level concentrations of auxiliary agents, it was classified into Not classified.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) of 100mg/kg (SIDS (2002)).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although it is water-insolubility and acute toxicity was not reported within the upper level concentrations of the auxiliary agents and there was no rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 0%(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data), since the bio-accumulation (log Kow=1.1 (PHYSPROP Database (2005))) was low, it was classified into Not classified.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: The substance contains chemical groups associated with explosive properties that contain nitrogen but lack oxygen. The decomposition heat is 1.3kJ/g (Bretherick (J) (5th, 1998)), while SADT stands at 50degC (Studies in Disasters (2002)). These data are not excluded from "explosives," but classification is not possible because of the absence of data. Classified into Division 4.1 (UN#3234) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests and germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo and negative data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo, described in CERI Hazard Data 2001-45 (2002).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Organic compounds containing no oxygen, fluorine and chlorine

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the description in CERI Hazard Data 2001-45 (2002): Abnormalities in nursing behavior and the death of newborns are observed at dosing levels toxic to dams.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available - melting point: 105degC (HSDB, 2005), test temperature: 140degC

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Not classified as explosives and "Not applicable" as oxidative solids and organic peroxides; the decomposition heat is 1.3kJ/g (Bretherick (J) (5th, 1998)), while SADT stands at 50degC (Studies in Disasters (2002)) - which correspond to "self-reactive substances." With no data available for classification, the substance is classified into "Type C," according to the classification by UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods: Self-reactive Substance C (Solid) (Thermal Control Required), Class (Category 4.1 Container: No Grade (UN#3234).

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Insufficient data available, though negative results were observed in rabbit eye irritation tests (SIDS (2002)).

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the testing data of rabbit skin irritation tests according to OECD Test Guideline 404 (SIDS (2002)), and negative results in human health effects (SIDS (2002)).

skin_sensitizer.rationale: Insufficient data available, though negative results were observed in animal studies (SIDS (2002)) and human health effects (SIDS (2002)).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence from animal studies including "hypertrophy of centrilobular hepatocytes (the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (1997)). The effects on the liver of experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 2.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
